user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CountSemDelete:
```c
int32 OS_CountSemDelete(osal_id_t sem_id)
{
    OS_object_token_t token;
    int32             return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_EXCLUSIVE, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, sem_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return_code = OS_CountSemDelete_Impl(&token);

        /* Complete the operation via the common routine */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete(return_code, &token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_CountSemDelete:
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
int32 OS_CountSemDelete_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_impl_countsem_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_count_sem_table, *token);

    if (sem_destroy(&impl->id) < 0)
    {
        return OS_SEM_FAILURE;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete(int32 operation_status, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    osal_id_t final_id;

    /* Clear the OSAL ID if successful - this returns the record to the pool */
    if (operation_status == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        final_id = OS_OBJECT_ID_UNDEFINED;
    }
    else
    {
        /* this restores the original ID */
        final_id = token->obj_id;
    }

    /* Either way we must unlock the object type */
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, &final_id);

    /* Give event callback to the application */
    if (operation_status == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_NotifyEvent(OS_EVENT_RESOURCE_DELETED, token->obj_id, NULL);
    }

    return operation_status;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I examined all provided functions and could not find any statically unreachable code fragments. Reasoning by function:

- OS_CountSemDelete: control flow branches on the result of OS_ObjectIdGetById; both the path taken when it returns success and the path when it returns an error are reachable at runtime depending on the called function's return value. There is no code after an unconditional return that would be dead.

- OS_ObjectIdGetById: the early return when OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit fails is reachable; the subsequent code that executes when that call succeeds is reachable. The conditional block that calls OS_ObjectIdConvertToken is entered for the success case. The transaction-cancel call is guarded by a non-success check and is reachable if any of the intermediate steps fail.

- OS_CountSemDelete_Impl: both branches (sem_destroy failure vs success) are reachable depending on the runtime return of sem_destroy; neither branch is syntactically dead.

- OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete: the two-way assignment of final_id is controlled by operation_status and both branches are reachable. The call to OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish is unconditional and reachable. The subsequent OS_NotifyEvent call is guarded by operation_status == OS_SUCCESS and thus reachable when appropriate.

No unconditional jumps, code after unconditional returns, or obviously dead/never-taken branches appear in the supplied code. Note: certain branches could be effectively never taken in a particular runtime configuration if the invoked functions always return a particular status, but that is a runtime property of those functions (not statically evident here) and not a static unreachable-code violation in the snippets provided.
